rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Attendance is mandatory and I suggest saying something every now and then. 80% of the exam material comes from powerpoints (which she posts online), and the other 20% from various readings. There's no HW, 1 map quiz of Africa, a book summary, a 10pg research paper, and midterm/final. She gives guides, which you should fill out and study for exams.

Dr. Lisanza is one of the best professors I have had at UNC. She is super nice, approachable, and makes lecture fun. Every once in a while she's a little unclear or confusing, but if you ask she will 100% clear it up. She's a great professor, really cares about the subject, and has cool anecdotes for every topic. Overall awesome and easy

Mwalimu Esther is one of the best teachers I've ever had. She'll teach you songs and have you play games that make it easy to learn Swahili. The book was not the greatest in quality but it doesn't really matter because Esther puts all of her own notes and lessons online that better explain everything. She's hilarious though and it's an easy A!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: This class directed me toward my major; I loved this class, although it's a lot of reading you learn so much about pastcontemporary Africa, and truly come out as a scholar; also, visit her office hours, they are great!

Sahle is NO help. She's unintelligible during lecture, she rambles and bounces around; she doesn't explain or define terms, she just gives arbitrary pseudo-examples and does not answer all student questions or follow the order of powerpoints.

Took Sahle for AFRI 101. She is a kind person. However she is not an effective teacher. My of the classtime was spent copying down her disorganized slide notes becuase she does not post her lectures to blackboard. Your final grade is based on attendance & participation, 2 exams and a research paper. Too many readings were assigned. The readings wer
Prof Sahle was a decent teacher. She tended to be absent-minded, but that was beneficial when she decided to cancel class and move back due dates continually. Good variety in lectures, movies, etc.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Great guy. Easy to talk to and have discussions with. Lots of group discussion the readings are interesting.
Easy grader, but showed tons of movies instead of lecturing.
Very nice guy. Easy grader. Lectures are a little boring, but he is very interested in the subject.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: David Pier is really nice and funny. AAAD 89 was about Afrofuturism that semester. You have to read about 4 small books. If you show up, everything will be okay. Midterm was easy and there was no final, instead there was a final project. You got to choose what your project was and he just approved it.

Dr. Pier was pretty amazing. I took his AAAD 101 class for a gen-ed & it ended up being my favorite out of 5! I never skipped a single lecture for 2 reasons: quizzes & discussions, which were engaging. Lots of readings to do, but they were very interesting & informative. Thanks to him I'm considering another class in the department. Def. recommend.

I love Professor Pier! He's hilarious and inspirational. He runs his class like a seminar, allowing you to ask questions or add comments at any time during lecture. We read from novels, so no textbook. It's not difficult to keep up with the reading and it's VERY interesting. Tests are easy if you read and take notes.
